conversation.content: Noch eine Gründerin hat alles verloren wegen einer liquidation preference. Warum lesen sie nicht die terms?

Ähm, term sheets sind absichtlich undurchsichtig, im Grunde, und Gründer werden, weißt du, emotional an die Schlagzeilen-Bewertung gebunden. Sie sehen eine Milliarden-Dollar-Zahl und ignorieren das 2x participating preferred, that guarantees they'll never see a dime.
Das Standard-NVCA-Template hat 28 Seiten voller Fallen.

Tja, jede Klausel bevorzugt Investoren, ich meine, von drag-along rights die Minderheitsverkäufe erzwingen bis zu, irgendwie, anti-dilution ratchets die das Gründer-Equity zerquetschen. VCs negotiate these daily while founders maybe see three term sheets in their entire career.
Was ist eigentlich die schlimmste Klausel, die Gründer, äh, übersehen heutzutage, irgendwie?
Verstehe. Full ratchet anti-dilution ist brutal - wenn die Bewertung auch nur leicht fällt, investors get compensated with massive equity grants while founders take the entire hit alone.
Board-Zusammensetzung bestimmt aber alles.

Absolut. Sobald Investoren das Board kontrollieren, werden Gründer zu Angestellten die von Firmen gefeuert werden können die sie erschaffen haben - Steve Jobs learned this lesson painfully at Apple in 1985.
Vesting-Zeitpläne starten nach jeder Runde neu.

Das ist das neue Playbook - 4-Jahre-Vesting mit einjährigen Cliffs die bei jeder Finanzierung neu starten bedeutet, founders never truly own their equity until exit, vorausgesetzt sie überleben so lange.
Option pool dilution trifft nur common shareholders.

Also, Investoren verlangen 20% option pools, ehrlich gesagt, aber berechnen es pre-money, ähh, was bedeutet dass Gründer die gesamte Verwässerung tragen. A $100 million valuation becomes $80 million after the pool shuffle - reiner mathematischer Taschenspielertrick.
Hmm, redemption rights sind, wie, Zeitbomben, die Sache ist.
Richtig richtig.
Wirklich, protective provisions geben, ah, Vetorecht über alles, es ist nur so dass Gründer es nicht realisieren.

Jede wichtige Entscheidung braucht Investoren-Zustimmung - Einstellungen, Kündigungen, Budgets, Pivots, sogar Schließung - founders become figureheads managing someone else's asset rather than leading their vision.
Okay also, pay-to-play provisions, ähm, zerstören frühe Investoren, siehst du.

Hmmm, später-stage VCs nutzen diese um, [whispering], Seed-Investoren rauszudrängen die nicht nachziehen können, richtig also, converting their preferred to common, tatsächlich. Es ist räuberischer Kapitalismus getarnt als skin-in-the-game-Erhaltung - smaller funds get completely wiped out.
Ähm, no-shop clauses fangen Gründer ein, denke ich, für Monate, nun ja.

60 bis 90 Tage exklusive Verhandlung klingt vernünftig bis du merkst dass es Hebel für Investoren ist um Bedingungen zu quetschen, while founders can't explore alternatives - Marktfenster schließen sich während Anwälte Kleinigkeiten durchstreichen.

original_conversation.content: Another founder just lost everything to a liquidation preference. Why don't they read the terms?

Um, term sheets are deliberately opaque, basically, and founders get, you know, emotionally attached to the headline valuation. They see a billion-dollar number and ignore the 2x participating preferred that guarantees they'll never see a dime.
The standard NVCA template is twenty-eight pages of traps.

Well, every clause favors investors, I mean, from drag-along rights forcing minority sales to, sort of, anti-dilution ratchets that crush founder equity. VCs negotiate these daily while founders maybe see three term sheets in their entire career.
What's the worst provision, actually, that founders, er, miss these days, kind of?
Gotcha. Full ratchet anti-dilution is brutal - if valuation drops even slightly, investors get compensated with massive equity grants while founders take the entire hit alone.
Board composition determines everything though.
Absolutely. Once investors control the board, founders become employees who can be fired from companies they created - Steve Jobs learned this lesson painfully at Apple in 1985.
Vesting schedules restart after every round now.
That's the new playbook - four-year vesting with one-year cliffs resetting at each funding means founders never truly own their equity until exit, assuming they survive that long.
Option pool dilution only hits common shareholders.

So, investors demand 20% option pools, honestly, but calculate it pre-money, uhh, which means founders bear the entire dilution. A $100 million valuation becomes $80 million after the pool shuffle - pure mathematical sleight of hand.
Hmm, redemption rights are, like, time bombs, the thing is.
Right right.
Really, protective provisions give, ah, veto power over everything, it's just that founders don't realize.
Every major decision requires investor approval - hiring, firing, budgets, pivots, even shutting down - founders become figureheads managing someone else's asset rather than leading their vision.
Okay so, pay-to-play provisions, err, destroy early investors, you see.

Hmmm, later-stage VCs use these to, [whispering], force out seed investors who can't follow on, right so, converting their preferred to common, actually. It's predatory capitalism disguised as maintaining skin in the game - smaller funds get completely wiped out.
Umm, no-shop clauses trap founders, I think, for months, well.

Sixty to ninety days of exclusive negotiation sounds reasonable until you realize it's leverage for investors to squeeze terms while founders can't explore alternatives - market windows close while lawyers redline minutiae.
